posts.name: Gavin
posts.cooked:
image 1330√ó408 33.9 KB I created a program that scrapes github to find what teams have a public repo of their robot code. I‚Äôve always wanted a list like this of reference material, so I hooked it up to statbotics and sorted by top 300 epa. These are all the public 2025 robot code github repos for every team in the top 300 by epa.

image 1330√ó408 33.9 KB

image 1330√ó408 33.9 KB

If theres interest I can run it for the remaining 3390 teams as well and we can make a comprehensive list.

Heres the spreadsheet I‚Äôve left it open to editing, so as a community maybe we could sort through these and categorize them (Like as main robot code, library code, other) to create a very helpful programming resource.

Is it smart to look at only top teams for programming examples? No absolutely not, but It‚Äôs still a good starting point. Not all top teams have good convention, but you can learn from them nontheless.

I ran this program on May 4th, so some teams that just released code like SPAM aren‚Äôt on there, but I can rerun it sometime soon.

In case you‚Äôre curious, it mostly just looks for "projectYear": "2025", in wpilibpreferences to sort by year (thanks to @kn4 for coming up with that), so theres some people‚Äôs 2024 offseason code and stuff like that in there as well, hence why I think the community sorting some of it could be helpful.

Let me know what you all think, if you published code accidentally and want to be removed also lmk.

posts.name: Gavin
posts.cooked:
Honestly I just couldn‚Äôt think of a better way to make it open to contributions and didn‚Äôt think malice would be an issue, any ideas for another way?

Additionally if anyone has ideas on what should be categorized feel free to share them, I‚Äôve started going through and marking if they include main robot code, or just supplemental or other public repos.

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked:
Gavin0:

any ideas for another way?

You can enable suggesting changes without editing.

posts.name: Gavin
posts.cooked: Sadly google sheets doesn‚Äôt have that for whatever reason, only docs. For now I changed it to comment only, if you want edit access just lmk and I can share it directly

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked:
I prefer to sort by the most important metric: total number of codebases. I guess we still have some work to do.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: We‚Äôre finally in the top . A bunch of those listed are forks by our kids to practice coding their own robot during the off-season.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: The Blue Alliance links to teams github organization. It would be great to get a list that could be imported there.
I am surprised 3481 isn‚Äôt higher there!

posts.name: Mert Ata BABER
posts.cooked:
Gavin0:

Honestly I just couldn‚Äôt think of a better way to make it open to contributions and didn‚Äôt think malice would be an issue, any ideas for another way?

Not sure if this is what you need, but a Google Form connected to Google Sheets for displaying responses would allow people to submit their codes without letting other people to edit the data that‚Äôs already displayed.

posts.name: Kabir
posts.cooked: On a related note, some time ago I made a search shortcut to do a github code search to find any individual team‚Äôs repo in a similar manner: https://github.com/search?q=%2F%22projectYear%22%3A+%222025%22%2C%5Cs%2B%22teamNumber%22%3A+%s%5Cn%2F+path%3Awpilib_preferences.json&type=code (instructions to add it to Chrome at Set default search engine and site search shortcuts - Computer - Google Chrome Help ).

link_counts.title: Set default search engine and site search shortcuts - Computer - Google Chrome Help

posts.name: Gavin
posts.cooked: If you sent this in the discord a while back, then you‚Äôre probably where I got the wpilibpreferences searching idea, so thanks for that!

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked: I think you can do a protected range in sheets, and protect the known good data.

posts.name: Ari
posts.cooked: Maybe its about time we changed our repo name from ‚Äúplaceholder-2025‚Äù

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: I love names like this that never get updated. At one of our competitions this year, we were working out of a branch called ‚Äútemp-auton-testing‚Äù

posts.name: Kabir
posts.cooked: I decided to search all the repos myself: 2025 repos - Google Sheets . Instead of individually searching for each team, I just used the code search API to find all the repos at once (splitting the searches by digits in order to not hit the github limit of 1000 results per search). There are a few inaccuracies due to stuff like copied example projects.

posts.name: Ari
posts.cooked: It seems like our repo actually is updated with the bot name. It just isn‚Äôt reflected on the first spreadsheet.

posts.name: Ethan C
posts.cooked: Hi, can I have edit access to add 2022‚Äôs codebase? Also, I‚Äôd like to take a shot at labelling some of the codebases by programming language.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: You could probably just look for ‚Äúrobot.‚Äù and then you have the extension right?
